title: SB 1.17.33 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 13-03-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiran Dhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya Chakshurun Militam Jena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: Therefore, O friend of irreligion, you do not deserve to remain in a place where experts perform sacrifices according to truth and religious principles for the satisfaction of the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam (1.17.33) and explains its meaning, focusing on the concept of irreligion and the exclusion of Kali Purusha from Parikshit Maharaj's kingdom.

segments.key_quote: So, he is addressing in this verse why is a personality like Kalipurusha not allowed to live in the kingdom of Pariksit Maharaj.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Parikshit Maharaj encountering Kali Purusha and explains why Kali was not allowed to remain in the kingdom, emphasizing the importance of truth, religion, and sacrifice in a place like Brahmavarta.

segments.key_quote: such sacrificial ceremonies are performed according to the scriptural directions, are prescribed differently in the scriptures for different ages.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the importance of performing sacrifices according to scriptural directions, highlighting that the methods of sacrifice vary in different ages (yugas).

segments.key_quote: In Satya yuga, most people are situated in the mode of goodness.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the characteristics of Satya Yuga, where people were spiritually inclined and focused on meditation, and contrasts it with the current age.

segments.key_quote: Kalavata Hari Kirtanath the method is a performance of Sankirtan Yajna
segments.summary: The speaker explains the recommended methods of sacrifice for Treta Yuga (fire sacrifice), Dwapar Yuga (temple worship), and Kali Yuga (Sankirtan Yajna).

segments.key_quote: Yajna ultimately means to please the Supreme Lord after accepting his supremacy he is the Supreme Personality, he is the Supreme Controller, he is Supreme Maintainer, he is Supreme well wisher, he is Supreme Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of accepting the supremacy of the Supreme Lord and obeying His orders, stating that all bona fide religions acknowledge one Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: all the religions aim at worship of this supreme lord obey his orders and ultimately as proper points out all religions ultimately aim at developing love for god
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Supreme Lord is known by different names in different religions and that all religions ultimately aim at developing love for God.

segments.key_quote: they want to perform actions for satisfying the supreme lord no matter which religious system they follow which is a bona fide religious system
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts theists and atheists, explaining that theists, regardless of their religious system, aim to satisfy the Supreme Lord, while atheists deny God's existence.
